issue.title: Removed the OQS_RAND object from the sig API
issue.body: Removed the OQS_RAND object from the sig API to harmonize with the KEM API (c.f., issue #374)

comment.body: Branch created on open-quantum-safe repo by mistake. Moving to my own fork.

issue.title: Move OpenSSH to new KEM API
issue.body:
Change our fork of OpenSSH so it uses our new KEM API.  

- Since the only KEMs currently on liboqs master branch are BIKE, FrodoKEM, and SIKE, this patch also removes NewHope and NTRU-based KEX methods in OpenSSH.
- This can be built against either liboqs nist-branch of liboqs master branch.
- It adds a "oqsdefault" KEX method that maps onto whatever the default KEM is in liboqs; see the updated README.md for an explanation of this functionality.

comment.body:
@crockeea 
Thanks. The problem was a typo when registering the default pq key exchange algorithm.

issue.title: Move OpenSSH to new KEM API
issue.body:
Change our fork of OpenSSH so it uses our new KEM API.  

- Since the only KEMs currently on liboqs master branch are BIKE, FrodoKEM, and SIKE, this patch also removes NewHope and NTRU-based KEX methods in OpenSSH.
- This can be built against either liboqs nist-branch of liboqs master branch.
- It adds a "oqsdefault" KEX method that maps onto whatever the default KEM is in liboqs; see the updated README.md for an explanation of this functionality.

issue.title: Remove kex_ntru (issue #370).
issue.body:
1st shot at removing kex_ntru.
https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/issues/370

References to ntru exist in the visual studio project files. I don't have windows at all, so didn't touch that part.

comment.body: All of the KEX stuff is going away as part of #372 so maybe it's easier to do that here?

issue.title: Refactored sig API
issue.body: Removed OQS_RAND object; harmonized params names with nist-branch. The sign/verify functions however remain. Fixes issue #374. Supersedes PR #375.

comment.body:
Let's do the change of the SIG algorithm identifier to a string on a separate PR.

Also, should we worry that the \_sign function in master branch has a different connotation than \_sign in nist-branch?  \_sign in master outputs just the digest, \_sign in nist-branch outputs the message and digest combined.  It's true that the verification functions are named differently (\_verify in master, \_sign\_open in nist-branch), but the signing functions have the same name.  Perhaps we should rename one of them so they are distinct (maybe call nist-branch \_sign\_combined?).

issue.title: Fixed typo in the registration of the oqs default algorithm
issue.body:
Fixes issue reported by @crockeea in #9 
`$make tests` returns no errors (Ubuntu platform).

issue.title: Remove rand object from sig API
issue.body: Remove the rand object from the sig API, to harmonize with the KEM API.

issue.title: Fixed typo in the registration of the oqs default algorithm
issue.body:
Fixes issue reported by @crockeea in #9 
`$make tests` returns no errors (Ubuntu platform).

issue.title: sshd_config Unsupported option
issue.body:
On AmazonLinux2, running `sudo make install` results in
```
/etc/ssh/sshd_config line 79: Unsupported option GSSAPIAuthentication
/etc/ssh/sshd_config line 80: Unsupported option GSSAPICleanupCredentials
```

comment.body:
@crockeea 
That is just a warning, right?

issue.title: Add shared library build to testing system
issue.body: On nist-branch we build `test_kem` (which statically links against liboqs.a) and `test_kem_shared` (which dynamically links against liboqs.so) and test both of them in Travis.  Is there a way to do that on master branch?

comment.body:
The failure has nothing to do with the message about utilities.c containing no symbols.

It has something to do with how clang tries to build static executables on macOS.

Run the following command on macOS:

```bash
CC_OVERRIDE=clang AES_NI=0 USE_OPENSSL=1 OPENSSL_DIR=/usr/local/opt/openssl .travis/all-tests.sh
```

The last few lines of output look like this:

```
Making all in .
  CCLD     liboqs.la
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/ranlib: file: .libs/liboqs.a(libkembike1_l1_la-utilities.o) has no symbols
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/ranlib: file: .libs/liboqs.a(libkembike1_l3_la-utilities.o) has no symbols
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/ranlib: file: .libs/liboqs.a(libkembike1_l5_la-utilities.o) has no symbols
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/ranlib: file: .libs/liboqs.a(libkembike2_l1_la-utilities.o) has no symbols
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/ranlib: file: .libs/liboqs.a(libkembike2_l3_la-utilities.o) has no symbols
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/ranlib: file: .libs/liboqs.a(libkembike2_l5_la-utilities.o) has no symbols
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/ranlib: file: .libs/liboqs.a(libkembike3_l1_la-utilities.o) has no symbols
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/ranlib: file: .libs/liboqs.a(libkembike3_l3_la-utilities.o) has no symbols
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/ranlib: file: .libs/liboqs.a(libkembike3_l5_la-utilities.o) has no symbols
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/ranlib: file: .libs/liboqs.a(libkembike1_l1_la-utilities.o) has no symbols
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/ranlib: file: .libs/liboqs.a(libkembike1_l3_la-utilities.o) has no symbols
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/ranlib: file: .libs/liboqs.a(libkembike1_l5_la-utilities.o) has no symbols
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/ranlib: file: .libs/liboqs.a(libkembike2_l1_la-utilities.o) has no symbols
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/ranlib: file: .libs/liboqs.a(libkembike2_l3_la-utilities.o) has no symbols
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/ranlib: file: .libs/liboqs.a(libkembike2_l5_la-utilities.o) has no symbols
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/ranlib: file: .libs/liboqs.a(libkembike3_l1_la-utilities.o) has no symbols
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/ranlib: file: .libs/liboqs.a(libkembike3_l3_la-utilities.o) has no symbols
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/ranlib: file: .libs/liboqs.a(libkembike3_l5_la-utilities.o) has no symbols
Making all in tests
make[2]: Nothing to be done for `all'.
checking for a BSD-compatible install... /usr/local/bin/ginstall -c
checking whether build environment is sane... yes
checking for a thread-safe mkdir -p... /usr/local/bin/gmkdir -p
checking for gawk... no
checking for mawk... no
checking for nawk... no
checking for awk... awk
checking whether make sets $(MAKE)... yes
checking whether make supports nested variables... yes
checking build system type... x86_64-apple-darwin17.7.0
checking host system type... x86_64-apple-darwin17.7.0
checking how to print strings... printf
checking for gcc... clang
checking whether the C compiler works... no
configure: error: in `/Users/dstebila/Desktop/liboqs-master':
configure: error: C compiler cannot create executables
See `config.log' for more details
```

Ignore the lines about utilities.o containing no symbols, those are just warnings.

Notice that liboqs.la was built successfully, then it says "Making all in tests", and then says "Nothing to be done for all", and then looks like it's running configure again.  This configure is what's failing.  I'm not actually sure why it's running configure again, but it apparently is.  If you look in config.log, you'll see how it fails.  On my system here is the relevant extract from config.log:

```
InstalledDir: /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin
configure:3969: $? = 0
configure:3958: clang -V >&5
clang: error: argument to '-V' is missing (expected 1 value)
clang: error: no input files
configure:3969: $? = 1
configure:3958: clang -qversion >&5
clang: error: unknown argument: '-qversion'
clang: error: no input files
configure:3969: $? = 1
configure:3989: checking whether the C compiler works
configure:4011: clang   -static conftest.c  >&5
ld: library not found for -lcrt0.o
clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
configure:4015: $? = 1
```

The key error message I think is "library not found for -lcrt0.o".  Googling this error message yields the following StackExchange discussion: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3801011/ld-library-not-found-for-lcrt0-o-on-osx-10-6-with-gcc-clang-static-flag

Can you investigate from there?

Following approach on nist-branch.

Also, should we worry that the _sign function in master branch has a different connotation than _sign in nist-branch? _sign in master outputs just the digest, _sign in nist-branch outputs the message and digest combined. It's true that the verification functions are named differently (_verify in master, _sign_open in nist-branch), but the signing functions have the same name. Perhaps we should rename one of them so they are distinct (maybe call nist-branch _sign_combined?).

comment.body: Perhaps instead call the master branch version \_sign\_digest and leave nist branch as \_sign?

Thanks.

issue.title: sshd_config Unsupported option
issue.body:
On AmazonLinux2, running `sudo make install` results in
```
/etc/ssh/sshd_config line 79: Unsupported option GSSAPIAuthentication
/etc/ssh/sshd_config line 80: Unsupported option GSSAPICleanupCredentials
```

comment.body:
@himsen Not clear what the severity is. Those are the last two lines of output from `sudo make install`, so it's not reporting any sort of failure. Here's my sshd_config file:

```
#       $OpenBSD: sshd_config,v 1.100 2016/08/15 12:32:04 naddy Exp $

# This is the sshd server system-wide configuration file.  See
# sshd_config(5) for more information.

# This sshd was compiled with PATH=/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin

# The strategy used for options in the default sshd_config shipped with
# OpenSSH is to specify options with their default value where
# possible, but leave them commented.  Uncommented options override the
# default value.

# If you want to change the port on a SELinux system, you have to tell
# SELinux about this change.
# semanage port -a -t ssh_port_t -p tcp #PORTNUMBER
#
#Port 22
#AddressFamily any
#ListenAddress 0.0.0.0
#ListenAddress ::

HostKey /etc/ssh/ssh_host_rsa_key
#HostKey /etc/ssh/ssh_host_dsa_key
HostKey /etc/ssh/ssh_host_ecdsa_key
HostKey /etc/ssh/ssh_host_ed25519_key

# Ciphers and keying
#RekeyLimit default none

# Logging
#SyslogFacility AUTH
SyslogFacility AUTHPRIV
#LogLevel INFO

# Authentication:

#LoginGraceTime 2m
#PermitRootLogin yes
#StrictModes yes
#MaxAuthTries 6
#MaxSessions 10

#PubkeyAuthentication yes

# The default is to check both .ssh/authorized_keys and .ssh/authorized_keys2
# but this is overridden so installations will only check .ssh/authorized_keys
AuthorizedKeysFile .ssh/authorized_keys

#AuthorizedPrincipalsFile none

#AuthorizedKeysCommand none
#AuthorizedKeysCommandUser nobody

# For this to work you will also need host keys in /etc/ssh/ssh_known_hosts
#HostbasedAuthentication no
# Change to yes if you don't trust ~/.ssh/known_hosts for
# HostbasedAuthentication
#IgnoreUserKnownHosts no
# Don't read the user's ~/.rhosts and ~/.shosts files
#IgnoreRhosts yes

# To disable tunneled clear text passwords, change to no here!
#PasswordAuthentication yes
#PermitEmptyPasswords no
PasswordAuthentication no

# Change to no to disable s/key passwords
#ChallengeResponseAuthentication yes
ChallengeResponseAuthentication no

# Kerberos options
#KerberosAuthentication no
#KerberosOrLocalPasswd yes
#KerberosTicketCleanup yes
#KerberosGetAFSToken no
#KerberosUseKuserok yes

# GSSAPI options
GSSAPIAuthentication yes
GSSAPICleanupCredentials no
#GSSAPIStrictAcceptorCheck yes
#GSSAPIKeyExchange no
#GSSAPIEnablek5users no

# Set this to 'yes' to enable PAM authentication, account processing,
# and session processing. If this is enabled, PAM authentication will
# be allowed through the ChallengeResponseAuthentication and
# PasswordAuthentication.  Depending on your PAM configuration,
# PAM authentication via ChallengeResponseAuthentication may bypass
# the setting of "PermitRootLogin without-password".
# If you just want the PAM account and session checks to run without
# PAM authentication, then enable this but set PasswordAuthentication
# and ChallengeResponseAuthentication to 'no'.
# WARNING: 'UsePAM no' is not supported in Red Hat Enterprise Linux and may cause several
# problems.
UsePAM yes

#AllowAgentForwarding yes
#AllowTcpForwarding yes
#GatewayPorts no
X11Forwarding yes
#X11DisplayOffset 10
#X11UseLocalhost yes
#PermitTTY yes
#PrintMotd yes
#PrintLastLog yes
#TCPKeepAlive yes
#UseLogin no
#UsePrivilegeSeparation sandbox
#PermitUserEnvironment no
#Compression delayed
#ClientAliveInterval 0
#ClientAliveCountMax 3
#ShowPatchLevel no
#UseDNS yes
#PidFile /var/run/sshd.pid
#MaxStartups 10:30:100
#PermitTunnel no
#ChrootDirectory none
#VersionAddendum none

# no default banner path
#Banner none

# Accept locale-related environment variables
AcceptEnv LANG LC_CTYPE LC_NUMERIC LC_TIME LC_COLLATE LC_MONETARY LC_MESSAGES
AcceptEnv LC_PAPER LC_NAME LC_ADDRESS LC_TELEPHONE LC_MEASUREMENT
AcceptEnv LC_IDENTIFICATION LC_ALL LANGUAGE
AcceptEnv XMODIFIERS

# override default of no subsystems
Subsystem sftp  /usr/libexec/openssh/sftp-server

# Example of overriding settings on a per-user basis
#Match User anoncvs
#       X11Forwarding no
#       AllowTcpForwarding no
#       PermitTTY no
#       ForceCommand cvs server
```

Note that `sudo make install` detects that sshd_config is already present, so it does not overwrite it. I think that means the config file pasted above is the default one shipped with AL2 (PAM is enabled by default).

issue.title: Add shared library build to testing system
issue.body: On nist-branch we build `test_kem` (which statically links against liboqs.a) and `test_kem_shared` (which dynamically links against liboqs.so) and test both of them in Travis.  Is there a way to do that on master branch?

comment.body:
The problem turned out to be very simple, instead of passing
LDFLAGS='-static' all that needs to be passed is --enable-shared=no for
static build.
That works fine on both Linux and Mac.

So static builds are not an issue on Mac.
Empty .o files generated by bike will only be an issue if we consider
-Werror.
Otherwise nothing spectacular.

issue.title: Change SIG algorithm identifier on master to a string
issue.body:
Following approach on nist-branch.

Also, should we worry that the _sign function in master branch has a different connotation than _sign in nist-branch? _sign in master outputs just the digest, _sign in nist-branch outputs the message and digest combined. It's true that the verification functions are named differently (_verify in master, _sign_open in nist-branch), but the signing functions have the same name. Perhaps we should rename one of them so they are distinct (maybe call nist-branch _sign_combined?).

comment.body: You are not forced to sign a digest with this API, so this could be confusing.

issue.title: sshd_config Unsupported option
issue.body:
On AmazonLinux2, running `sudo make install` results in
```
/etc/ssh/sshd_config line 79: Unsupported option GSSAPIAuthentication
/etc/ssh/sshd_config line 80: Unsupported option GSSAPICleanupCredentials
```

comment.body: @crockeea There is no severity. The reason you get warnings, as you also say, is that the build is checking the AL2 sshd_config. I have an idea why, but I would need to know the exact commands you used when building. Could you add them here, please?

issue.title: sshd_config Unsupported option
issue.body:
On AmazonLinux2, running `sudo make install` results in
```
/etc/ssh/sshd_config line 79: Unsupported option GSSAPIAuthentication
/etc/ssh/sshd_config line 80: Unsupported option GSSAPICleanupCredentials
```

comment.body:
@himsen 
```
git clone https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh-portable.git
cd openssh-portable
autoreconf
./configure --with-pam --with-liboqs-dir=/usr/local/ --enable-pq-kex --enable-hybrid-kex --prefix=/usr --sysconfdir=/etc/ssh
make
sudo chmod 600 /etc/ssh/ssh_host_ed25519_key
sudo chmod 600 /etc/ssh/ssh_host_rsa_key
sudo chmod 600 /etc/ssh/ssh_host_ecdsa_key
sudo make install
```

issue.title: sshd_config Unsupported option
issue.body:
On AmazonLinux2, running `sudo make install` results in
```
/etc/ssh/sshd_config line 79: Unsupported option GSSAPIAuthentication
/etc/ssh/sshd_config line 80: Unsupported option GSSAPICleanupCredentials
```

comment.body: @crockeea Thanks. You can choose another directory (e.g.  `/usr/local/etc/ssh`) for the config files by passing that directory to the `sysconfdir` option.
